content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is very good for a very hard puzzle.
i kinda like it
its ok but i think its really involved with math

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's funny, well explained and well coded

~~~~~
1~43~
~~433
2~44~
2~~~~

Is this an alternative solution to your example?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice puzzle!!
The puzzle fits his difficulty.
I solved the puzzle in C#.

I think it would be better for people that trying to solve it to try to solve Nurikabe's puzzles by hand so they will understand the logic. That what I did and it was very helpful. So maybe you can add a link to a website that you can solve there  Nurikabe's puzzles, like: https://www.puzzle-nurikabe.com/
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Wow, I was able to solve all the tests except of Test 8 and Validator 11 :grinning:

Edit: Solved all the tests!

I will approve the contribution when you will allow to do it.

Edit: Like you said in the statement, it: "requires pure logic, no particular math knowledge is necessary",  and I totaly agree with this.
I think it would be better for people that trying to solve it to try to solve Nurikabe's puzzles by hand so they will understand the logic. That what I did and it was very helpful. So maybe you can add a link to a website that you can solve there  Nurikabe's puzzles, like: https://www.puzzle-nurikabe.com/
I've never seen this puzzle before, I like sudoku, this is nice-and-compact, and I'd like to try solving it on codingame, so I'm upvoting.

Like the puzzle!!
Maybe you can mention that islands cannot be connected to each other (except diagonally), and that  islands surface cannot be bigger than 9.

Note: If you added this already, I am sorry that I didn't notice.
nice
Hey Q12, I added the maximum of 9. The non diagonal connection is in the formal rules section, do you think it would be clearer if I also added it before the example ?

Good job ! I will set the contribution to ready after the WIP time has passed.

Edit : good idea, I added the link.
Not because of this rule : All islands are isolated from each other horizontally and vertically. Basically they can't touch.
Thanks !
Got it. Thanks

No, it is clear. You can also learn it from viewing the tests. How are you by the way :slight_smile: ?

I have to say that I feel that many hard puzzles left abounded and unchecked by the community because of their difficulty. Do you feel the same?
In my puzzle for example, except you :slight_smile: (thanks), no one try to solved it, I think.

Yes same, but it's hard to blame people when it takes several hours to come up with a proper solution. Ofc you already have a solution for the puzzle when it comes out. Or rather "if" it comes out, which is why not many people invest in tough contributions.
You just have to be patient I guess :)

Thanks, I understand why they prefer not to solve it, I also feel like this, because of this I decided to try to solve those puzzles.
Maybe CG should do something about it (like reward the people that try to solve the puzzle). Maybe I will make a topic about it in the forum.

Hope your contribution will be approved soon :slight_smile:
I will approve it as soon as I will be able to solve it (If I even can :sweat_smile:)

Tried to solve it in C#, was able to solve just Test 1, Validator 1, Test 2, Validator 2, Validator 3 :grin:
This puzzle totally deserve to be Very Hard :slight_smile:
I am trying to optimize my code now.

This one can't be done with brute force alone :)
You have to massively reduce the search space by applying as much logic as possible. Finding which logic to apply and how to code it properly is the difficult part.

Yeah, I knew this won't be solved just by brute force, I add already some of the logic.

I find now that I need to add the part that two different islands cannot be connected.

Edit: I can solve with my code the following tests:
Test 1, Validator 1, Test 2, Validator 2, Test 3, Validator 3, Test 4, Validator 4 and Test 5.
